msDesc.head: Hugo de S. Victore, In Ecclesiasten; Hrabanus Maurus, In Macchabaeos

msItem.incipit: Fol. 1r. Que de libro salomonis qui ecclesiastes dicitur
msItem.explicit: Fol. 84v. vt possit postmodum fructum operis sui in gustu percipere.
msItem.author: Hugo de S. Victore
msItem.title: In Ecclesiasten
msItem.note: Our text ends mid-page in the middle of Homily XIV (PL 175. 230 B 4), although three more prepared but unused pages follow (fols. 85r-87v).

msItem.rubric: Fol. 88r. Incipit prologus Rabani Mauri ad giroldum sacri palacij archidiaconi
msItem.finalRubric: Fol. 88v. Explicit prologus Capitulorum libri primi Machabeorum
msItem.incipit: Et factum est post-quam percussit Alexander
msItem.explicit: et quartadecima mensis adar habite pariter iungerenter [sic]. Explicit.
msItem.author: Hrabanus Maurus
msItem.title: In Machabaeos

listBibl.bibl: prologue also pr. by E. Dümmler, MGH, Epist. V/3 (1898-9), 424-5;

msItem.note: From fol. 125v/8 Quod [sic] hereticos (PL 109. 1159/15) to fol. 128r/8 facit amicos (PL 109.1164/18) is a repetition of fol. 118r/15 Quia hereticos to fol. 122v/10 facit amicos. The scribe became aware of his error at that point; on every duplicated page he wrote va at the top and cat at the bottom, in red (also after fol. 128r/7), discarded six or perhaps eight unwanted leaves between fols. 127/128, and continued with Et occidit omnem masculum (PL 109. 1159/15). Fol. 127v ends euangelij ag- (as fol. 120v/9, PL 109. 1161.48), resuming moliuntur eos gladio impietatis occidere (PL 109.1164/11) on fol. 128r. Fols. 216-18, 220-2 are the leaves discarded from after fol. 127 (fol. 219 and its preceding, unnumbered, stub are unprepared for writing and were never used: the reason for their insertion is obscure). The original six-leaf quire is inside out: fols. 220r-222v were written on ruled pages but after it was realized that they were unwanted an attempt was made to wash them. Fols. 220r-221r were quite successfully washed and could have been reused but as fol. 221v is only partly washed the procedure may have been considered unsatisfactory and it was left in that state and no more leaves were washed. To avoid wasting the entire quire it was turned inside out and the unused leaves, now fols. 216-18, were used for the last quire of the book. The unwanted, duplicated, text on fols. 221v-222v begins at PL 109. 1161/26 and ends at PL 109. 1164/11. Fol. 219rv is blank.

supportDesc.support:
Written on 222 membrane leaves vary¬ing in quality from very good to quite good, preceded by 6 medieval membrane flyleaves.
Foreleaves: fol. ir, number; fols. iv-vir, blank; fol. viv, titles.
supportDesc.foliation: Leaves are numbered in modern pencil.
supportDesc.collation: Collation: 1-108 118 (wants 8, ?blank) 12-278 288 (wants 4). The first two leaves of the preliminary quire are stuck together to form a double pastedown, with leaves (unnumbered) conjunct with fols. v, vi. A quire of six or perhaps eight leaves was removed between fols. 127 and 128 (see above, item 2), where the catchword does not run on. Catchwords bottom right offinal leaves of quires, in scribe's hand. Up to the catchword on fol. 56 they are in boxes, usually with a face in profile drawn out of the left side of the box. Quire signatures in a cursive hand at bottom right of versos beginning with quire 2 in a sequence +a-k (fols. 1-87) a-r (fols. 88-218). In these the letters are in ink, the figures in crayon and written at a different time. In each quire the signatures run to the fourth leaf.
supportDesc.condition: Some leaves were repaired before use and have subsequently been trimmed at both sides and at the bottom.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in one column, 182 115 33 lines. Pricked in outer margins and for vertical ruling. Ruled in crayon. Folded FSOS.

handDesc.handNote: Scribe 1, fols. 1-49r/5, wrote bastard anglicana. Scribe 1 is very good.
Scribe 2, fols. 49r/6-49v/12, wrote anglicana formata. Scribe 2 is inferior.

Scribe 3, fols. 49v/13 to the end including the reject leaves, wrote bastard anglicana. Scribe 3 is the best. Scribes 1 and 3 are very similar. As scribe 3 proceeds his hand becomes less neat and more spread out but although beginning and end look different they merge imperceptibly. Rubrics were written by scribe 3. Punctuation is by low point.
Running titles in red in item 2 were written by a fourth, less skilled, hand, perhaps that of an owner.

decoDesc.decoNote: On fols. 1r and 88r are three-line gold initials on a blue and crimson background traced with white and with marginal floreation.
There are three-line and two-line blue lombards flourished red, and letters stroked with red throughout.
Red running titles. Directions to the rubricator are in the margins, erased. For rubrics see Script above. Alexander and Temple, no.478.

binding.p: Sewn on seven bands on slightly projecting bevelled oak boards covered with white alum-tawed sheepskin. On the front cover are the remains of two straps, each held by three nails of the usual type. Further down the front cover are four holes from a chain-staple (position 4). On the back cover are two metal strap-catches. The pastedown on the back cover is fol. 5v of a copy of the Margarita poetica of Albrecht von Eyb, of which other leaves are in MSS 2, 12, 13, 30, 79, and dd.2.9: see MS 12 for details. On the spine is a black leather lozenge-shaped label with 10 on it. The end-bands are blue and white, the edges are yellowed, and there is a fore-edge title.

history.provenance:
On fol. 2r is ex libris style 1, Liber collegij Animarum omnium fidelium defunctorum in Ox' Ex dono domini W. Folowys [sic] preceptoris quondam gramatice apud Euesham qui obiit 4 die Augusti Anno d' 1483. <Oretis igitur pro anima eiusdem>. On him see BRUO, Felowys, William: he also gave books to Magdalen, Merton, and Oriel Colleges. Listed in the Vellum Inventory (MS 399): Ker, All Souls, List XIII, no. 996 with books on the theology side, In secundo dextu in media parte. No. 1432 (31) in CMA.
All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, inside the front cover, bookplate no. 10, vv.3.6, ww:5.10 (both deleted), 93 (pencil), P<...>, and MS.14 (figures added). On fol. ir is 7.3. On fol. vi is Anonymus in Ecclesiasten Rabanus Mauris in Machab in a good italic hand of s. xvi and also a post-medieval symbol which looks a little like a q and is found also in MSS 12 and 30.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.
